intro: Mentha subspicata, commonly known as hedge mint, is a perennial herb native to Europe and parts of Asia. It belongs to the mint family, Lamiaceae, and is characterized by its square stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, pale blue or purple flowers that are clustered in spikes, giving it its species name "subspicata." Its aromatic leaves contain essential oils, which contribute to its distinctive menthol scent and make it useful in herbal remedies. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in woodland areas or along stream banks.
